biomarkers.name: Horvath DNAm Clock
biomarkers.measurement_method: Illumina EPIC Array (DNA methylation at 353 CpG sites)
biomarkers.notes: Pan-tissue biological age predictor. Accuracy ±3.6 years

biomarkers.name: GrimAge Clock
biomarkers.notes: Best predictor of mortality and healthspan among epigenetic clocks

biomarkers.name: PhenoAge Clock
biomarkers.notes: Composite clinical biomarkers + DNA methylation

biomarkers.name: Telomere Length
biomarkers.notes: Flow-FISH superior to qPCR for clinical use (CV <5%)

biomarkers.name: p16INK4a T-cell expression
biomarkers.notes: Doubles every ~8 years. Predicts response to dasatinib+quercetin

biomarkers.name: IL-6 (Interleukin-6)
biomarkers.notes: The cytokine for gerontologists. Central to inflammaging

biomarkers.name: CRP (C-Reactive Protein)
biomarkers.notes: Standard marker of systemic inflammation

biomarkers.name: TNF-α (Tumor Necrosis Factor-alpha)
biomarkers.notes: Pro-inflammatory cytokine, NF-κB pathway activation

biomarkers.name: GDF15 (Growth Differentiation Factor 15)
biomarkers.notes: Strongest mortality-associated SASP biomarker from senescent cells

biomarkers.name: NAD+ (Blood)
biomarkers.notes: 50-80% decline by age 70-80. Critical for sirtuin and PARP function

biomarkers.name: Pulse Wave Velocity (PWV)
biomarkers.notes: Gold standard for arterial stiffness. 6-8% increase per decade

biomarkers.name: VO2 Max
biomarkers.notes: ~10% decline per decade (sedentary), 5.5% (athletes). Exercise training: +16.3% increase

biomarkers.name: Heart Rate Variability (HRV)
biomarkers.notes: Most significant decline between 2nd and 3rd decades. Low HRV: 4-9% higher lifetime CVD risk

biomarkers.name: Carotid Intima-Media Thickness (cIMT)
biomarkers.notes: 2-3 fold increase from age 20-90

biomarkers.name: Testosterone (Total)
biomarkers.notes: 1-2% annual decline in men after 30. Women: 50% reduction by menopause

biomarkers.name: Estradiol (E2)
biomarkers.notes: Dramatic decline during perimenopause to 10-20% of premenopausal levels

biomarkers.name: IGF-1 (Insulin-like Growth Factor 1)
biomarkers.notes: 29% decline per decade. Longevity paradox: reduced signaling associated with longevity

biomarkers.name: TSH (Thyroid Stimulating Hormone)
biomarkers.notes: Age-dependent reference ranges. Treatment threshold ≥7 mIU/L in elderly

biomarkers.name: Vitamin D (25-hydroxyvitamin D)
biomarkers.notes: 13% decrease per decade. By age 70: ~50% of age 20 production. 2024 guidelines: supplement >75 years

biomarkers.name: DHEA-S (Dehydroepiandrosterone Sulfate)
biomarkers.notes: 29% decline per decade. By age 70: ~20% of peak. By 85-90: 80-95% decline

biomarkers.name: Cortisol (Diurnal Pattern)
biomarkers.notes: Basal hyperactivation with age. Flatter diurnal slope = dysregulation. Lower diurnal cortisol correlates with longevity

biomarkers.name: Glucose (Fasting)
biomarkers.notes: Insulin resistance characteristic of normal aging

biomarkers.name: HbA1c (Glycated Hemoglobin)
biomarkers.notes: 3-month average glucose. Age-related increase due to insulin resistance

biomarkers.name: FOXO3A Genotype (rs2802292)
biomarkers.notes: Most robust longevity gene. G allele protective. Homozygous minor allele: OR=2.75 for longevity

biomarkers.name: APOE Genotype
biomarkers.notes: ε2 protective (+1 year lifespan), ε4 detrimental (-1.2 years). ε4: 3-12x AD risk

biomarkers.name: Mitochondrial DNA Copy Number
biomarkers.notes: Decreased copy number = mitochondrial depletion

biomarkers.name: ATP Production Capacity
biomarkers.measurement_method: Oroboros respirometry or Seahorse assay (muscle biopsy)
biomarkers.notes: ~8% decline per decade in skeletal muscle. At age 70: ~60% of age 20 capacity

biomarkers.name: Grip Strength
biomarkers.notes: Strong predictor of all-cause mortality

biomarkers.name: Gait Speed
biomarkers.notes: Simple, powerful predictor of survival in older adults

biomarkers.name: SA-β-galactosidase Activity
biomarkers.notes: Lysosomal β-galactosidase at pH 6.0. Not specific alone; requires ≥2 senescence markers (ICSA)

biomarkers.name: Plasma Protein Age (1,664 proteins)
biomarkers.notes: 1,664 proteins increase with age, 665 decrease. Non-linear aging at ~41, 60, 67 years

biomarkers.name: Organ-Specific Aging (Brain)
biomarkers.notes: Predicts Alzheimer's risk. Performance comparable to pTau-181

biomarkers.name: Organ-Specific Aging (Heart)
biomarkers.notes: 250% increased heart failure risk with accelerated heart aging

biomarkers.name: γH2AX Foci (DNA Damage)
biomarkers.notes: Phosphorylated H2AX marks DNA double-strand breaks. 9.2x increase from age 20-80

biomarkers.name: Somatic Mutation Burden (Blood)
biomarkers.notes: 14 SNVs/cell/year in fibroblasts. Linear accumulation

biomarkers.name: Advanced Glycation End-Products (AGEs)
biomarkers.notes: Excellent markers across ALL subcellular compartments. Non-enzymatic modifications accumulate with age

biomarkers.name: Protein Carbonylation
biomarkers.notes: Irreversible PTM. Causative role in protein aggregation (experimentally proven)

biomarkers.name: 8-oxo-dG (Oxidative DNA Damage)
biomarkers.notes: Marker of oxidative DNA damage. Urinary excretion increases with age

biomarkers.name: IL-1β (Interleukin-1 beta)
biomarkers.notes: Key inflammasome-activated cytokine. NLRP3 inflammasome activation increases with age

biomarkers.name: IL-8 (Interleukin-8)
biomarkers.notes: Chemokine associated with inflammaging and SASP

biomarkers.name: Insulin (Fasting)
biomarkers.notes: Insulin resistance characteristic of aging. Combined with glucose for HOMA-IR

biomarkers.name: HOMA-IR (Insulin Resistance Index)
biomarkers.notes: Gold standard surrogate for insulin sensitivity

biomarkers.name: Creatinine (Serum)
biomarkers.notes: Used to calculate eGFR. Muscle mass affects interpretation

biomarkers.name: eGFR (Estimated Glomerular Filtration Rate)
biomarkers.notes: ~1 mL/min/1.73m² decline per year after age 40

biomarkers.name: Total Cholesterol
biomarkers.notes: Increases with age, peaks in 50s-60s, may decline in very elderly

biomarkers.name: LDL Cholesterol
biomarkers.notes: Primary target for CVD prevention

biomarkers.name: HDL Cholesterol
biomarkers.notes: Protective against CVD. Lower levels in elderly

biomarkers.name: Triglycerides
biomarkers.notes: Increases with age and metabolic syndrome

biomarkers.name: Mitochondrial ROS Production
biomarkers.notes: Mitochondrial superoxide increases with age, damages cellular components

biomarkers.name: Complex I Activity
biomarkers.notes: Primary site of mitochondrial dysfunction in aging

biomarkers.name: Complex IV Activity (Cytochrome c Oxidase)
biomarkers.notes: Marker of mitochondrial function, declines with age

biomarkers.name: Melatonin (Nocturnal)
biomarkers.notes: Peak production declines with age. Important for circadian rhythm and sleep quality

biomarkers.name: Leptin
biomarkers.notes: Increases with age and adiposity. Leptin resistance develops

biomarkers.name: Adiponectin
biomarkers.notes: Anti-inflammatory adipokine. Low levels predict metabolic syndrome

biomarkers.name: Free Thyroxine (FT4)
biomarkers.notes: Active thyroid hormone. Levels decline with age

biomarkers.name: Free Triiodothyronine (FT3)
biomarkers.notes: Most active thyroid hormone. Conversion from T4 declines with age

biomarkers.name: Growth Hormone (GH)
biomarkers.notes: Pulsatile secretion declines ~14% per decade after puberty

biomarkers.name: Free Testosterone
biomarkers.measurement_method: Calculated from total testosterone and SHBG
biomarkers.notes: Bioavailable fraction. More accurate indicator of androgen status than total

biomarkers.name: SHBG (Sex Hormone-Binding Globulin)
biomarkers.notes: Increases with age, reducing free testosterone. Inversely correlates with insulin resistance

biomarkers.name: FSH (Follicle-Stimulating Hormone)
biomarkers.notes: Rises dramatically with ovarian aging in women

biomarkers.name: LH (Luteinizing Hormone)
biomarkers.notes: Rises with age due to gonadal decline

biomarkers.name: Homocysteine
biomarkers.notes: Rises with age, B-vitamin deficiency. Independent CVD risk factor

biomarkers.name: Albumin (Serum)
biomarkers.notes: Declines with age. Strong predictor of mortality in elderly

biomarkers.name: Prealbumin (Transthyretin)
biomarkers.notes: More sensitive than albumin for nutritional status

biomarkers.name: Ferritin
biomarkers.notes: Increases with age. High levels associated with inflammation and oxidative stress

biomarkers.name: Neutrophil-to-Lymphocyte Ratio (NLR)
biomarkers.notes: Simple, powerful inflammatory marker. Predicts mortality, CVD, and cancer

biomarkers.name: CD4+/CD8+ T-cell Ratio
biomarkers.notes: Inverted ratio indicates immunosenescence. CD8+ expansion with age

biomarkers.name: Naive T-cell Percentage
biomarkers.notes: Declines with age due to thymic involution. Limits response to novel pathogens

biomarkers.name: Klotho (Serum)
biomarkers.notes: Anti-aging protein. Regulates phosphate metabolism, insulin signaling, and oxidative stress

biomarkers.name: Cystatin C
biomarkers.notes: Superior to creatinine for eGFR. Not affected by muscle mass

biomarkers.name: NT-proBNP (N-terminal pro-B-type Natriuretic Peptide)
biomarkers.notes: Gold standard biomarker for heart failure. Increases with age and cardiac stress

biomarkers.name: Troponin I (High-Sensitivity)
biomarkers.notes: Detects subclinical cardiac injury. Baseline levels rise with age

biomarkers.name: Lipoprotein(a) [Lp(a)]
biomarkers.notes: Genetically determined, stable across life. Independent CVD risk factor

biomarkers.name: ApoB (Apolipoprotein B)
biomarkers.notes: Superior to LDL for CVD risk. One ApoB per atherogenic particle

biomarkers.name: Uric Acid
biomarkers.notes: Increases with age, metabolic syndrome. Also an antioxidant

biomarkers.name: ALT (Alanine Aminotransferase)
biomarkers.notes: Elevated levels common with NAFLD, which increases with age

biomarkers.name: AST (Aspartate Aminotransferase)
biomarkers.notes: AST/ALT ratio useful for differentiating liver conditions

biomarkers.name: GGT (Gamma-Glutamyl Transferase)
biomarkers.notes: Marker of oxidative stress and alcohol consumption. Predicts CVD and mortality

biomarkers.name: Hemoglobin
biomarkers.notes: Mild decline with age. Anemia common in elderly

biomarkers.name: White Blood Cell Count
biomarkers.notes: Total count may decline. Shifts in differential (increased neutrophils, decreased lymphocytes)

biomarkers.name: Platelet Count
biomarkers.notes: Generally stable with age. Low count increases bleeding risk

biomarkers.name: Bone Mineral Density (BMD)
biomarkers.notes: Accelerated loss postmenopause (women) and after age 70 (both sexes)

biomarkers.name: Vitamin B12
biomarkers.notes: Deficiency common in elderly due to reduced absorption

biomarkers.name: Folate (Serum)
biomarkers.notes: Important for DNA synthesis and homocysteine metabolism

biomarkers.name: Serum Amyloid A (SAA)
biomarkers.notes: Acute phase protein, increases with inflammation and infection

biomarkers.name: Fibrinogen
biomarkers.notes: Acute phase reactant. High levels predict CVD events

biomarkers.name: D-dimer
biomarkers.notes: Fibrin degradation product. Baseline increases with age

biomarkers.name: MicroRNA-21 (miR-21)
biomarkers.notes: Upregulated with age and cellular senescence. Pro-inflammatory SASP factor

biomarkers.name: Hannum DNAm Clock
biomarkers.notes: Blood-specific clock. Accuracy ±3.9 years. Predicts mortality and age-related disease
